I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The Government of Armenia is committed to developing comprehensive policy reforms in 
the education and health sectors. These reforms will enable the government to improve the 
efficient utilization of resources and quality of services in these two social sectors. Support for 
these social sectors is consistent with the strategic focus of the country partnership strategy, 
2014–2018 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for Armenia.1  
 
2.  The government has asked ADB to provide support through the policy-based lending (PBL) 
modality, which will include two subprograms to tackle development challenges in the education 
and health sectors. Dialogue with the government on reform is substantially advanced with regard 
to education, but at an early stage for health. Thus, the first subprogram will focus mainly on 
education sector policy reform and include initial support for policy reform in the health sector, 
while the second subprogram will increase support for health sector reform. The ensuing project 
and  the  transaction  technical  assistance  (TRTA)  are  currently  included  in  ADB’s  country 
operations business plan, 2018–2020, for Armenia.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
3.  The TRTA is justified given the wide-ranging nature of the activities supported by the 
Armenia Social Sector Reform Program, the innovative nature of key aspects of the PBL, and the 
specialist  nature  of  the  skills  required  in  areas  such  as  the  expansion  of  the  education 
management and information system (EMIS), development of teacher standards, health facility 
master planning for integrated care, and review of medical curricula. The TRTA will provide 
technical inputs and assessments to help the government and ADB develop PBL that is aligned 
with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2014–2018 for Armenia, the Armenia Development 
Strategy for 2014–2025, and the Perspective Development Strategic Program 2014–2025. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
4.  The TRTA has the following outputs: 
 
(i)  Assessment of the State Program of Education Development 2017–2025, and 
the  provision  of  technical  support  for  implementation  planning.  The 
assessment  will  focus  on  formulating  short-,  medium-,  and  long-term  reform 
priorities  and  rationalization  plans,  and  a  related  set  of  progress  indicators. 
Emphasis will be placed on priorities and activities that are necessary to improve the 
quality and labor-market relevance of students’ educational outcomes and skills, 
pursue  institutional  reforms  and  better  coordination,  and  improve  sustainable 
financing and efficient resource allocation in the sector.  
(ii)  Support  for  the  planned  expansion  of  the  education  management  and 
information system, to cover all levels of education. The support will help 
improve the functions of the current EMIS and develop a set of comprehensive

indicators to support evidence-based, timely policy formulation and implementation 
in the sector effectively.  
(iii)  Support for the development of national teacher standards, modern teacher 
training programs, and professional development programs for educational 
leaders. This output will focus on the development of comprehensive national 
teacher  training  standards  and  programs  that  align  pre-service  and  in-service 
teacher training in basic and secondary education, and professional development 
programs for school principals and leaders of educational institutions to improve 
governance, management, and capacity for resource planning at these levels. The 
support t will help develop pathways for career progression and related incentives in 
the sector, and link them with standards and training. 
(iv)  Assessment of public financial management systems in the social sectors. 
This output will focus on budget design, execution, funds allocation, key financing 
functions such as purchasing, and opportunities to integrate financing for vertical 
programs.  The  assessment  will  include  an  analysis  of  the  formal  planning, 
budgeting, and execution system to describe how these funds flow through different 
administrative levels, and the implementation of these budgets. This description will 
document as much as possible the cost of an inefficient public financial management 
system in education and health. 
(v)  Assessment of the optimization of primary health care and hospitals through 
an integrated health care model. This output will support the Ministry of Health in 
transitioning toward more efficient health service delivery through integrated care.2 
To assess this, it is necessary to review the current governance, management, and 
organizational structure; services; and rules, responsibilities, and accountability for 
decision-making.  The  roles  and  independence  of  primary  health  centers  and 
hospitals should be clearly defined within the lines of accountability to the central 
structure, as well as the need to coexist and support the government’s strategic 
direction. 
(vi)  Assessment of the medical education system and programs. This assessment 
will examine the current medical education system, including continuous medical 
education, and its effectiveness in teaching practical clinical skills. It will look at the 
existing curricula and syllabi of medical programs, as well as courses and modules 
for continuous medical education, and will recommend improvements to the current 
system, focusing on quality improvement and teaching facilities.

C.  Cost and Financing 
6.  The technical assistance is estimated to cost $800,000, which will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The government will provide 
counterpart support through counterpart staff, provision of office space, communication facilities 
for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
1. The government was informed that approval of the TRTA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing PBL. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
7.  ADB will administer the TRTA. The Ministry of Education and Science and Ministry of 
Health will be the executing agencies. The Social Sector Division of the Central and West Asia 
Department will coordinate the preparation of the PBL with the Ministry of Education and Science 
and Ministry of Health. The TRTA will be implemented from January 2018 to July 2019 and will 
be coordinated with other development partners. Disbursements will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time).

8.  Consulting services. A team of 13 experts is required to meet the program’s outputs and 
activities. The experts will be engaged as individual consultants for the preparation of the 
subprograms, and will include nine international experts (for a total of 32 person-months) and four 
national  experts  (for  a  total  of  39  person-months).  The  consultants  will  be  considered  for 
engagement on time-based contracts. Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the  associated  project 
administration instructions and technical assistance staff instructions.

III.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
9.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Armenia for Social Sectors Reform Program, and hereby reports this action to the 
board.
